item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: April 20
item.description: Arrest in Boston bombing; new risky investments; drug maker under scrutiny, and moves against tax evasion.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: In China, the Shared Grief of Losing a Single Child Like Lu Lingzi
item.description: With their daughter’s death in the Boston Marathon attack, the parents of Lu Lingzi joined a growing group in China — parents who lose a single child in a country that mandates one child for many.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A woman holding a baby on a Beijing street. The Chinese government's strict controls on family size, including a one-child policy for some, especially urban families, has limited population growth but also created a sizable group of parents who have lost their only children.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: After Boston and Tsarnaevs, Russians Urge U.S. to Rethink Chechnya
item.description: Despite strained relations with Washington, the Kremlin has offered its help in the Boston bombing investigation. Russian commentators suggest a Chechen connection to the attack may force the U.S. to reconsider how it sees Moscow’s own war on terror.
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: Tamerlan Tsarnaev, 26, left, and Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, 19.

item.title: The Lede: Latest Updates on the Boston Blasts
item.description: The Lede is following the aftermath of Monday’s deadly explosions at the Boston Marathon, which killed three and injured more than 170 on Monday.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A screenshot from a WBZ Boston broadcast, showing an image of the boat authorities believe the suspect in the Boston Marathon bombings was hiding in late Friday.

item.title: North Korea Is Said to Move Missile Launchers
item.description: North Korea has moved two missile launchers in an indication that it is pushing ahead with preparations for a test launching, a South Korean news agency reported on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: China Quake Kills Many and Injures Thousands
item.description: The earthquake struck the western region of Sichuan Province, where a previous quake killed 70,000 people.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:credit: Color China Photo, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A woman whose house was destroyed by an earthquake in Sichuan Province on Saturday.

item.title: Kerry Says U.S. Will Double Aid to Rebels in Syria
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry said the $123 million in new aid would be used to provide “nonlethal” supplies to the military wing of the Syrian opposition.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
National Coalition of Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and SEBNEM ARSU
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry in Istanbul on Saturday.

item.title: Tamerlan Tsarnaev’s Citizenship Held Up by Homeland Security
item.description: Department of Homeland Security officials had decided not to grant an application for American citizenship by Tamerlan Tsarnaev after a routine background check revealed that he had been interviewed by the F.B.I.
item.dc:creator: By JULIA PRESTON

item.title: The Lede: Updates on Aftermath of Boston Marathon Explosions
item.description: The Lede is following the aftermath of Monday’s deadly explosions at the Boston Marathon, which killed three and injured more than 170.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Red Sox fans remembered the Marathon bombing victims at Fenway Park on Saturday.

item.title: Danes Rethink a Welfare State Ample to a Fault
item.description: With little fuss or political protest — or notice abroad — Denmark has been at work overhauling entitlements, trying to prod Danes into working more or longer or both.
item.dc:creator: By SUZANNE DALEY
item.media:credit: Jan Grarup for The New York Times
item.media:description: Robert Nielsen, 45, said proudly last year that he had basically been on welfare since 2001.

item.title: Italian Lawmakers, After Stalemate, Re-elect President to Second Term
item.description: Amid growing political chaos, lawmakers on Saturday elected President Giorgio Napolitano for a second term, in an effort to break a profound deadlock in the euro zone’s third-largest economy.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO and RACHEL DONADIO
item.media:description: President Giorgio Napolitano in February. He would become the first second-term president in Italy’s 67-year old republic.

item.title: U.S. Financier Backs China Scholarship Program
item.description: Stephen A. Schwarzman, head of the Blackstone Group, is creating a scholarship program with mostly Western corporate donors to bring future leaders to study in Beijing.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: The financier Stephen A. Schwarzman is creating a scholarship program at Tsinghua University in Beijing.

item.title: Bombing Suspects’ Immigration Story Adds Layer to Debate on Overhaul
item.description: Some opponents of immigration reform are pointing to the Boston attack as cause for concern about expanding visa programs and offering illegal immigrants a path to citizenship.
item.dc:creator: By TRIP GABRIEL

item.title: Devastation and Frustration in Aftermath of Quake
item.description: People slept outside ruined homes and tried to reach relatives in Lushan County in China, only to be turned away by the police because of a landslide.

item.title: Suspects With Feet in Two Worlds
item.description: A small glimpse at life in the Russian republic of Dagestan, which was once home to Tamerlan and Dzhokhar Tsarnaev.

item.title: Boston Suspects: Confused Identities and Conflicting Loyalties
item.description: The case of the Boston suspects recalls that of other young men who, caught between life in America and loyalty to fellow Muslims in a distant homeland, turned to violence.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SHANE
item.media:description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation released this image of Dzhokhar A. Tsarnaev.

item.title: Relatives of Flotilla Raid Victims Reject Israeli Compensation
item.description: The relatives of the nine people killed in Israel’s raid on a Turkish-led flotilla to Gaza in 2010 also said that they would not drop their lawsuits against those involved in the raid.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU and JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Italian Bureaucracy Threatens Pompeii
item.description: Conservationists warn the city is dangerously exposed to the elements, and is poorly served by red tape, lack of strategic planning and limited personnel of the site’s troubled management.
item.dc:creator: By RACHEL DONADIO and ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pompeii's decline has captured the attention of the European Union, which began an effort in February aiming to balance preservation with accessibility to tourists.

item.title: WORLD: Pompeii Falling From Grace
item.description: Pompeii’s ruins are a Unesco World Heritage site, but despite money from the European Union, the Italian government is struggling to maintain them.

item.title: Italian Bureaucracy Threatens Pompeii
item.description: A site no stranger to misfortune, the ancient city must now face a possible new hazard: Italy’s red tape.

item.title: Boston Attacks Turn Spotlight on Troubled Chechen Region
item.description: With the Chechen background of the suspects in the Boston attacks, questions arise about a connection to the bloody conflict in the Russian republic of Chechnya, which has appeared calm for some time.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER and C. J. CHIVERS

item.title: Iraq’s First Vote Since U.S. Exit Is Mostly Calm
item.description: Limiting violence is one gauge of success, but observers are also waiting to see whether the results will embolden the prime minister to expand power along sectarian lines.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO
item.media:description: Residents at a polling station in Baghdad on Saturday. Iraqis voted for local councils, which will give clues to the political strength of various parties before parliamentary elections next year.

item.title: Rape in India of Girl, 5, Sets Off New Furor
item.description: An attack and the police response struck a chord in the nation, still dealing with the trauma of another brutal rape case.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:description: Protesters converged at Swami Dayanand Hospital in New Delhi on Friday as shock spread in the Indian capital over the alleged rape and abduction of a 5-year-old girl by a neighbor. The girl, said to be in critical condition, was being taken to a larger facility.

item.title: Tensions High After Riot at Syrian Refugee Camp in Jordan
item.description: Ten Jordanian security officers were injured by stone-throwing protesters in the camp of 120,000 Syrian refugees.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By RANYA KADRI and JODI RUDOREN

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Americans Learn of Chechnya
item.description: Marcus Mabry, Rendezvous’s editor, speaks to Clifford J. Levy, the former Moscow bureau chief of The New York Times, about the Chechen origins of the suspected Boston Marathon bombers,Tamerlan and Dzhokhar Tsarnaev.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
